image.altText: The Rajah Quilt 1841 at Quilts exhibition.

props.synopsis: It's a piece of Australia's colonial-era history, a quilt sewn by convict women on a ship and presented on arrival in Van Diemen's Land, 182 years ago. It is hidden away in a store room in Canberra — but now, the push is on for the Rajah Quilt to come back to Tasmania.

title.children: The Rajah Quilt was sewn in 1841 on a convict ship. A playwright wants it returned home

image.altText: A bright pink Telstra van with the words "Australia's largest regional network" on the side, driving in a remote area.

props.synopsis: Telstra's "pink bus" travels to remote communities to help Indigenous clients, but financial counsellors have concerns the outreach service is not helping victims of mis-selling get the compensation they're entitled to.

title.children: Telstra's pink bus waived a woman's debt. Later, she found out she was also entitled to $12,000

image.altText: Woman's hand holds a credit card in front of a computer

props.synopsis: Scammers are creating fake websites that replicate popular brands during Black Friday sales, but experts say paying attention to red flags can help you avoid getting caught out.

title.children: Scam shopping sites have raked in $500,000 this year. Here's how to spot them on Black Friday

image.altText: Farmer' market produce on a table.

props.synopsis: During the pandemic the virtual farmers' market concept took off across Australia and business boomed. Now it's evolving, with one Tasmanian collective hosting more than a dozen collection points.

title.children: Producer-led farmers' market cuts out the middle man to sell direct to customers

image.altText: Photo of older woman with short hair standing behind open door with living room behind her

props.synopsis: Pensioner Gail Couchman was living on an old bus before she found an affordable rental home thanks to the efforts of her local Lions Club.

title.children: The town where pensioners can rent new units for $200 per week

image.altText: Probiotic variety

props.synopsis: Probiotics that fill supermarket shelves promise to boost your digestion and immune system. Some even claim they can help people with an irritable bowel or low mood. Let's look at the evidence.

title.children: Yoghurt vs probiotics. Which is better for restoring that good gut bacteria?

image.altText: Children on a roof drop a bucket of water on children standing on a suburban street in the middle of the day

props.synopsis: Last week, the planet appeared to briefly breach a climate threshold set by world governments for the first time. Experts say it is just another sign of how much the planet is warming.

title.children: Earth briefly surpassed a crucial temperature milestone last week. Experts say there's more to be worried about

image.altText: Benjamin Netanyahu in an all-black outfit standing at a lecturn

props.synopsis: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says he has told US President Joe Biden he will press ahead with Israel’s war against Hamas after a temporary ceasefire expires. Follow live.

title.children: Netanyahu vows war will continue after ceasefire as Israeli strikes on Gaza continue

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: School strikes for Palestine continue today in Sydney
27 dead after Israeli strike on UN school in Gaza, Palestinian doctor says

image.altText: A plume of smoke rises above a city dotted with buildings.

props.synopsis: As part of a temporary ceasefire deal that is due to begin as early as today, Hamas will begin releasing Israeli hostages in exchange for Palestinian prisoners. But with thousands more remaining in detention inside Israel and hundreds of captives in Gaza, there is still a long way to go.

title.children: These are some of the Palestinian prisoners who could be released as part of the Israel-Gaza hostage deal

image.altText: A water bomber drops water on a burning house

props.synopsis: Fire crews spend a second night battling a large bushfire in Perth's north-east, with better conditions offering some respite for residents.

title.children: Bushfire emergency continues in Perth's north-east as firefighters seize on 'favourable' change

image.altText: Julia Garner and Jessica Henwick squint in the outback, wearing huge backpacks, in the film The Royal Hotel.

props.synopsis: The Royal Hotel probes the darker side of masculinity as magnified by a remote outback setting and alcohol consumption on a liver-defying scale — and evokes the spectre of horror without ever actually letting it loose.

title.children: 'Gonna have to be OK with male attention': Australian drinking culture through the eyes of two outsiders

image.altText: A woman with long brown hair is at a standup desk in focus. Another woman on another computer with blonde hair can be seen.

props.synopsis: Employers monitoring their workers' computer keystrokes might seem intrusive, but it's just one of the many ways workplace surveillance is being carried out today.

title.children: Whether you work from home or in the office, here's how 'Big Brother' employers might be watching you

image.altText: People wearing masks sit in a crowded hospital waiting room.

props.synopsis: Chinese health authorities have provided data requested by the World Health Organisation (WHO) on an increase in respiratory illnesses and reported clusters of pneumonia in children.

title.children: Leading scientists urge caution over new pandemic fears amid pneumonia clusters in China

image.altText: A man on the roof of a burning skyrise has a crane cage landing next to him

props.synopsis: A crane operator plays down tributes paid to him after he lifted a man to safety from a burning high-rise building in England.

title.children: Crane operator rescues man from roof of burning high-rise in England

image.altText: a man wearing glassed stands next to a flag looking sideways

props.synopsis: The government says it has agreed to 'all 56' of the Robodebt royal commission's recommendations. So then why does the report list the number as 57?

title.children: We fact checked Mark Dreyfus on the Robodebt royal commission recommendations. Here's what we found

image.altText: A person holds an iPhone with the banking apps for ANZ, Commonwealth Bank, NAB and Westpac open.

props.synopsis: Australia's banks will announce a joint effort to tackle a rise in scams and prevent customers from being victims of cybercrime, while the local share market is set for a quiet start after Thanksgiving saw Wall Street closed overnight. Follow live.

title.children: Australian banks join forces to tackle rise in scams, muted start for ASX after Thanksgiving shuts Wall Street

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: The six measures our banks will be rolling out to combat scams
Banks join forces to tackle scams, ASX headed for a quiet start after US Thanksgiving

image.altText: View of Strahan town on river.

props.synopsis: The plight of the endangered Maugean skate could see a pause to salmon farming in Tasmania's Macquarie Harbour. But locals warn the flow-on effects to their small community could be disastrous.

title.children: Strahan is famous for salmon farms and tourism. Will both die to save a threatened species?

image.altText: Electricity power lines in a rural Tasmanian setting

props.synopsis: A series of billion-dollar projects, ranging from wind farms to an eFuel factory, have been proposed for Tasmania's north-west. But uncertainty over electricity transmission line upgrades has raised fears their viability could be undermined.

title.children: Tasmania aims to be the 'battery of the nation'. But a change of plan has left some 'bewildered'

image.altText: A group of young kids at a childcare centre standing around a table with toy dinosaurs

props.synopsis: The productivity commission is urging the federal government to modify the childcare subsidy to increase access to early childhood education for children from all backgrounds.

title.children: Earning under $80k? A new report says you should get free childcare

image.altText: A wall with Gordana spray painted on it next to a photo of Gordana with brown curly hair

props.synopsis: Graffiti on several inner-city buildings has appeared in Newcastle, marking the 29th anniversary of schoolgirl Gordana Kotevski's abduction after a trip to the local shopping centre.

title.children: Graffiti in memory of abducted schoolgirl Gordana Kotevski mysteriously appears in Newcastle

image.altText: three kids in school uniforms bend over bubblers

props.synopsis: In the sunshine state, councils have ultimate authority over whether there's fluoride in their water supply. Some say it's too expensive, others are wary of anti-fluoride campaigners.

title.children: This simple public health policy has been adopted by most of Australia. But in Queensland, it’s a controversial topic

image.altText: Police with riot shields confront a group of people on a road at night

props.synopsis: Ireland's police chief refuses to rule out any motive, including terrorism, after five people, including three young children and the suspect, were injured in central Dublin.

title.children: Five people, including three children, in hospital after Dublin stabbing

image.altText: Queenstown from above

props.synopsis: A male Tasmanian nurse who a tribunal has found "poses a serious risk to persons in his care" will be allowed to keep practising, so long as he is always supervised, documents show.

title.children: Nurse found by tribunal to pose 'serious risk to persons in his care' allowed to keep licence

image.altText: a middle aged man with short grey hair slightly smiling

props.synopsis: As political tensions mount ahead of the 2024 Summer Olympics, the Australian Olympic Committee president has warned athletes against protesting at official ceremonies.

title.children: Australia's top Olympic Games official warns athletes against protesting on the podium

image.altText: Rain clouds over Wattamondara

props.synopsis: Rain is falling onto dry farms, dry gardens and empty water tanks, much to the relief of farmers and firefighters after a very dry couple of months.

title.children: Heavy rain 'taking the sting' out of intense drought conditions in Australia's parched regions

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann walks away as a TV camera films him.

props.synopsis: It's the first time the former Liberal staffer has told a court his version of events on the night of the alleged rape.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann admits he was 'mistaken' in some evidence he gave police about night of Brittany Higgins's alleged rape

image.altText: a woman looks at hostage posters set up on a fence

props.synopsis: The four-day truce is set to start on Friday morning (local time) according to Qatar which mediated the deal and confirmed by Hamas, with a first batch of hostages to be released later in the day.

title.children: Qatar says 13 hostages to be released Friday as Hamas says temporary ceasefire with Israel confirmed

image.altText: A man at the centre of a media scrum, gesticulates and answers questions

props.synopsis: Despite its unrelenting announcements the federal government is struggling on key issues. After successful trips to Washington and Beijing, prime minister Anthony Albanese is suddenly looking on the back foot.

title.children: A bad patch, the lobster test, and Anthony Albanese's difficult year

image.altText: The inside of an office, with square carpet tiles and two rows of chairs.

props.synopsis: A psychosocial risk survey of more than 1,000 employees of Tasmania's state-owned electricity provider uncovers allegations of bullying, assault and sexual assault, with the boss saying he is "confronted" by the result.

title.children: Staff psychosocial surveys are 'new ground' for companies. This one just uncovered hundreds of concerns

image.altText: High school students observing female teacher demonstrating ingredient measurement in cooking class.

props.synopsis: Hannah Blackmore says unruly students are making her reconsider her choice of career, but there are hopes a training program will give teachers the tools to better manage in the classroom.

title.children: Passionate teacher going home in tears as job conditions leave her questioning capability

image.altText: A man in hospital, hooked up to drips, with shut eyes

props.synopsis: A snake catcher in north-west Victoria says he was so busy he did not realise a highly venomous reptile had bitten him on the finger. Then he started to lose consciousness.

title.children: 'Overworked' snake catcher collapses after he was bitten and didn't know it

image.altText: Two photos of two young girls overlap each other

props.synopsis: It's been more than 35 years since the deaths of Mona Lisa and Jacinta "Cindy" Smith, and the family continues to question what exactly happened that night, and how their two girls ended up dead.

title.children: More than 35 years on from the deaths of Mona Lisa and Cindy, their family is still waiting for answers

image.altText: University student Sophy Barlow has trouble accessing her classes

props.synopsis: Following COVID lockdowns, it's clear flexible study works. So why aren't universities taking a "more proactive approach" to ensure people of all abilities can access higher education?

title.children: Sophy missed out on two of her uni classes because there was no way for her to get into the room

image.altText: panoramic image of mansion on mountain with sea scape in background

props.synopsis: The federal police attempt to enforce a US restraining order in Australia to take control of a New South Wales South Coast mansion being sold by Daniel Duggan's wife to fund his legal bills.

title.children: 'Lapdog diplomacy' at work in AFP's property freeze over former US pilot on conspiracy charge, lawyer says

image.altText: A three-panel image showing the mugshots of three young men.

props.synopsis: Two prisoners who walked out of a north Queensland prison have been arrested while a third remains on the run.

title.children: Two arrested, man on the run after Queensland prison escape
